title: Do you title a book before or after writing it? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends on you writing style, and what your goal is. If you put the title before, you got yourself a fixed story, it means you have to be sure of what your story is and what it is focused on in a way that no matter where your story goes, it will always come back to the main idea behind the title. If you put the title after, you got a flexible story, it means you have an idea of what you want, but you don’t know for certain where it’ll go from there, your focus on the story varies, sometimes the focus will go to this character’s development, and then it will focus on another character in a different place, never to come back to the first character that appeared in the story. Sometimes even the goal of the story will change. You delay the writing of the title so you have a proper title at the end of the book that covers a general idea of the goal or setting in your story. An example of fixed story: The Harry Potter Saga, by J.K Rolling. She goes wild in imagination with her magic universe, It ran for more than 5 books, and the main characters encounter many challenges, but the spotlight always goes back to Harry Potter, the hero of the story. An example of a fixed story with a flexible title: Twilight Saga. The title had nothing to do with the story (which focused in the relationship and environment surrounding the main characters), it just sounded cool. An example of flexible story: Wonder, by R.J Palacio. She hits the spotlight with a multi-perspective story that holds the attention of the reader in more ways than one, it has one main story to follow, yes; but she gives you many magnifiers, each that will make you read her story in ways you have not seen on the other magnifier. Additional Notes: A good book is bound to follow a good story. Being flexible or fixed doesn’t change that fact. However, have in mind that being a flexible writer is much more difficult than being a fixed writer, since you don't really have a safe-place. This means that you don’t have a guide to go back to in case you lose your way with plot twists, developements, character's deaths, etc., If your story goes south when you meant it to go North, you will probably end up deleting everything from the moment you started to go South, which sometimes can be pages.

A book title is, in my opinion, the ribbon or card for a gift. Yes, you can wrap a gift with a non-descript wrapper. But, without a ribbon or card on it, the gift just looks incomplete and unspecial. Besides, how are we going to know that the gift is for us, from whom it came from or if it is even a gift if there are no cards nor ribbons? I think it is the same about a book title. I once wrote a short story. I let (or rather, forced) my classmates read it so I can gain their honest opinion about it. Being a careless kid, I forgot to put a title. Do you know what they told me about the story? “So, what’s the title?” That was their first “opinion” of my story. Therefore, it doesn't really matter if you have written a great piece. Readers always notice the title first, during and last. Now, let us go into the question! (Sorry for stalling. haha) Do you title a book before or after writing it? In my case, it depends on the...uhm...theme or idea I got. For example, I had this story about a vampire. I am...not going into deets. But, I did not write a title at first. I let the story go on until I finished the first scene. Then, I got inspired and titled it. Second, I once wrote a title after I had finished the story. So, mostly, I write my book title in my essay or story at the end or during the writing. If you ever need any help with writing, you can always check my bio! I hope I helped you.

I normally title the book long before I start writing it. Having just released a book the other day, I have a list of 4 titles on the to-do list, 1 of which potentially has 5 sequels, and another is potentially another series book 1, but not decided yet. I do occasionally change a title while writing, but not often. If the title isn’t self evident 3/4 of the way through writing, I’d say there is a problem. By then, the book should be focused enough for the title to be obvious to you. If you don’t have a title by the time you finished the book, I’d say something is very very wrong, and it will need a decent editor to sort out why you didn’t get a title for it. There has to be something lacking. Blurbs are the same. It’s very rare for me to not have the blurb down before the book is complete. After completion, if the blurb isn’t in you head, the book is lacking in some way.

Only once in 29 books have I known how the book will end when I started writing. Every other time, the book’s focus has changed, often dramatically as ideas have developed. The one time I knew what would happen was with a school project, one of many, when the idea was that a little girl, a brilliant cello player would in the last chapter, end up playing the Elgar Cello Concerto with the Sydney Symphony Orchestra under Vladimir Ashkenazy. In order to write it, I met with Ashkenazy, Principal Cello Katie Hewgill and Concert Master Dene Olding in the Green Room of the Sydney Opera House to ask their consent to being part of the story. This ended up like this:  But even then, the title wasn’t settled until the book was finished. In most other works, I settled on a title anytime after about half way through the writing process.

Well everyone has a different opinion about this question..some do like to fix a title and proceed there writings in accordance to the topic…but there are also people like me ,who after writing full stuff only gives name to the topic. According to me,title should have a relevant connection with the subject of your body,and sometimes even after writing 100 pages of your book,we feel confused what should actually be the suitable title.I feel the best solution for this is to take a temporary title in mind and proceed your writings and complete it first and then after go through your writings….you never no…the appropriate title may be somewhere hidden behind the body of your writings. But in overall,I want to say one thing you might follow either of the choices,but try to give a title that can connect even the front,middle as well as the ending parts of your writing!!

I do it before, during and after. I learned this trick from the software trade. You have a working name that the project lives under. You let the marketing people do whatever it is they do and you keep making the software. Eventually, the marketing people get told to bring it home because the software is going to be released and you join the two up. (Brochures are made, websites built, whatever…) I give my work a title, I change it when I feel like it, when it is done, I might give it yet a new name. I don’t marry the name. The name is just the project name for the book until we get down to the end. That way, I don’t have to be stuck on something that doesn’t fit. But I still get the benefit of working under a specific working title. I recommend this approach and if you do something like it you won’t dig in your heels when a publisher suggests a different title. Or when you decide the original title is garbage.

Evan, I normally title a book before I begin. Generally speaking, the title has to be over the top, and I have to have at least a very vague idea of what the story is about. Then I go from there. Long about 2002, I very quickly jotted down the titles of a series as they came to me. There were about 21 titles. Thus far I’m on book 17 of that series, with the first 16 having achieved some success. There are a couple of titles that really stood out, and I believe that they have sold better than others because of their titles. One was The Devil To Pay, but the best of the lot was Longnecks And Twisted Hearts. So, title! I hope this helps. All the Best!

I use a working title, as many times, after the story is finished, I feel the title I started with needed to change. It is purely personal preference, I know some authors who don’t title their story until they are ready to publish, while others spend ages thinking of a title before they start their first chapter. The only thing I would advise, is don’t let your worries about having the perfect title, stop you from writing the book itself. If you really can’t think of anything, finish your book, then share it with a few beta readers and ask them for an opinion on their title choices. Thank you for your A2A and good luck :)

Personally speaking, me and my friend are writing a book together and we started last year, but the thing is, we wrote the story line and not the book. We wrote the events coming in the book and wrote down the main plots of that book. After finishing the story line, we thought of its name and called it “Chain’s of Revenge.” We choose that name after deciding what is it the book. We called it that because there was fighting and people continuously taking revenge on the other because of someone they loved had died thanks to them and it was an ongoing cycle.

I think there may be two points of view. Let's consider both. First, you already have a great headline and you want to come up with a story. This is often the case, and if you come up with a cool headline, you don't have to give it up. If you feel that the title fits your book, that it is what you want to write about, then you should not refuse and you can consider the title as a beacon. This is a fairly common situation and you can use it in your favor. Secondly, if you don't have a title yet, but have an idea, it's logical to start writing down the idea and only then come up with a title. In this case, you don't have to make up the title yourself, you can ask your friends to help you choose the title. As you can see, there is no clear recipe. But if the name of the book is not there yet, it is better to give it a draft title.

It varies. R.L. Stein of “Goosebumps” and “Fear Street” fame usually starts with a great title and never starts writing a book without having a good title. This is because he doesn’t just want to write, he wants to sell, and he respects the power of a title. Thus, he will discard a perfectly amazing idea if he can’t produce a great title for it. His time is more valuable than that. I am not R.L. Stein. I just plunge into it, believing I’ll be able to come up with something attractive and intriguing eventually. It doesn’t work.

As a writer, I usually title my book after writing it. I always based my titles on the events or the outcome theme of my works, sometimes, as I write, a simple yet strong words will suddenly pop up in my mind. I’ll just jot that down, and when I finished my writing, I’ll finallize it and choose an appropriate title for my book. It can be one of those “pop up” words or a combination of those.

That’s a really interesting question. My current novel didn’t have a title until just recently ( 60,000 words and counting) but there are a couple of unfinished novels on my computer waiting to be written that already have titles, so…. On the one hand I don’t think titles are too important( the publisher may well change it anyway) and secondly, I think it’s important, for me anyway, not to get too hung up on the title.

That is completely up to you. You are the author of it, so you decide. If you feel you can’t get any words on a page, without the title, put one. However, be aware that as you go on your book writing journey, it may change, because honestly, you are simply the vessel so by the time you are finished the title you picked out, may absolutely change, and that is okay. Go with your gut and your heart. The book is your baby, you know it best and you will know what is the best title for it.

Oh god. I am in the 5th year of my 4th novel, having been interrupted by #s 1,2, 3 and a screenplay I won’t talk about. #4 has had a dozen titles and the pressure mounts to brand it as I am about 80% done. So title it when you can. I have plenty of other titles, I collect them, but not the right one yet. I envy the composers. Truly.

I doubt there's a rule to it. Sometimes a phrase hits you that gives you an idea for a story, and you may use it for the working title. It may be, however that the story takes off in a different direction so you change it or perhaps use it for a chapter title. Maybe your publisher loves the content of the story but suggests a different title. Just flow with the go

There’s nothing to stop you starting with a title that you feel is a stunner, but then you need to make it work AND be just as stunning. You don’t want to give birth to one of literature’s great let-downs after all! In any case, you may decide on a more appropriate title as you go along. There’s nothing set in stone while we’re writing (not even our own immortal prose). Maybe get the book written first - then worry about the title. If you’ve got a goer, your agent may have some title suggestions you could consider too.

After, when the whole story is fresh in your mind and you are more likely to apprehend it in a few words. Anyway, I never got good at giving titles. Neither to mind them while reading or studying, which is even worse because you miss the birds eye view to whatever content.

Before writing we all need to think, what we are going to write. It gives us a platform of easy going. The theme, rubric, suspense, conclusion all before penning the maiden letter of the book. So, think and carve out a small note to pen down your theme, title and conclusion. Hope, you are satisfied.

I don’t. The title is always the last piece. I learned by trial and error. Every title-first approach resulted in either stilted poetry or a reworking of the title. The piece will suggest a name for itself at some point.

I never start to write a book until after I have decided upon a title. The title is a point of focus. It helps me keep my work in progress on target as I go. It is also a heading that I wish to live up to as I spend some serious thought on a good title.

It depends on the author. The title you give the book is going shape the way its written. For example, if you name a book “The mystery of the dead guy” it isn't going to turn out to be a book on cooking! ;)

you start a book if you have a purpose or topic or title on your mind, then you write a book about it and when you are done and you still think that the topic you chose earlier ,suits the best, then you keep it. otherwise, you were not just able to….

Normally I find the title during the writing process whe. I write a line and I like a word or two in that line. The only one that had a title at the beginning was a job on commission and I had no option to change the title

Usually you start with a “working title” to create a computer file and a name for your project. This is meant to be temporary, though a lot of publishers will change a title at the last moment before its printing.
Both,if you know what you want to write clearly, you can title your book before. But people is always in change,title before or after is all depend on your mind.
Yes
Thanks for the A2A. During, usually. Until that title is created, I use a working title as a placeholder.
After. The title usually pops into my mind halfway through. Though the first idea is not necessarily the final.
I give it a parliamentary title that matches the outline, then modify the title if needed after completing the book.
This may occur at any time before or after. And change a number of times in the process.
After.
